qas.question: Artifacts from which era suggest that the moon was used to reckon time around 6,000 years ago?
Which calendars were among the first to appear?
How long were the original lunar calendars?

answers.text: either 12 or 13 lunar months (either 354 or 384 days)

context: Artifacts from <a0_0><b5_0><b10_0>the Paleolithic<b10_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/> suggest that the moon was used to reckon time as early as <b6_0>6,000 years ago<b6_0/>. <a1_0><b11_0>Lunar calendars<b11_0/><a1_0/> were among the first to appear, <a2_0>either <b12_0>12 or 13 lunar months (<b7_0>either 354 or 384 days<b12_0/><b7_0/>)<a2_0/>. Without intercalation to add days or months to some years, seasons quickly drift in a calendar based solely on twelve lunar months. Lunisolar calendars have a thirteenth month added to some years to make up for the difference between a full year (now known to be about 365.24 days) and a year of just twelve lunar months. The numbers <b8_0>twelve<b8_0/> and thirteen came to feature prominently in many cultures, at least partly due to this relationship of months to years. Other early forms of calendars originated in <a3_0><b9_0><b13_0>Mesoamerica<b13_0/><b9_0/><a3_0/>, particularly in ancient Mayan civilization. These calendars were religiously and astronomically based, with <a4_0><b14_0>18<b14_0/><a4_0/> months in a year and 20 days in a month.
